qas.question: What was tuberculosis called in 19th-century England?
How many deaths out of every six in France during 1918 were attributed to tuberculosis?
In what decade was TB's communicability finally realized?
What did Britain try to get people to stop doing to reduce the spread of TB in public?
What were the "treatment" facilities for poor people with TB in the early 1900s called?
How many deaths in France were caused by TB in 1815?
When were deaths from TB in England reduced to one in six?
When did France put TB on the notifiable disease list?
What percent of people who contracted TB died?
Where did poor people get excellent healthcare?

context: Tuberculosis caused the most widespread public concern in the 19th and early 20th centuries as an endemic disease of the urban poor. In 1815, <b5_0>one in four<b5_0/> deaths in England was due to "<a0_0>consumption<a0_0/>". By <b6_0>1918<b6_0/>, <a1_0>one<a1_0/> in six deaths in France was still caused by TB. After TB was determined to be contagious, in the <a2_0><b7_0>1880s<b7_0/><a2_0/>, it was put on a notifiable disease list in Britain; campaigns were started to stop people from <a3_0>spitting<a3_0/> in public places, and the infected poor were "encouraged" to enter <b9_0>sanatoria<b9_0/> that resembled prisons (the sanatoria for the middle and upper classes offered excellent care and constant medical attention). Whatever the (purported) benefits of the "fresh air" and labor in the <a4_0>sanatoria<a4_0/>, even under the best conditions, <b8_0>50%<b8_0/> of those who entered died within five years (circa 1916).
